The pound has peaked at $1.4118 against the dollar, for the moment at least. But it is still up 0.7% so far today at $1.4097. Connor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said: A green-gilled greenback and a half decent UK jobs report made for a very strong Wednesday for the pound. Kicking the currency while it was down, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin claimed at a press conference in Davos that a weaker dollar is good for the countryâ€™s economy â€˜as it relates to trade and opportunitiesâ€™. This turned an already bad morning worse for the greenback, with the currency falling 0.4% against the euro, where itâ€™s sunk to a fresh 3 and a bit year nadir, and 0.7% against both the yen and the pound. Sterlingâ€™s gains against the dollar caused cable to flit about the $1.41 mark for the first time since the Brexit referendum result back in June 2016. The pound didnâ€™t stop there, however; it also rose 0.4% against the euro, lifting back to its best price in just shy of 7 weeks. The FTSE wasnâ€™t best pleased with all this, dipping 0.2% as it continued to shed its early 2018 record-breaking momentum. The pound was aided by a UK jobs report that by and large didnâ€™t ruffle any feathers. Wage growth came in unchanged at 2.5%, and rose to from 2.3% to 2.4% excluding bonuses â€“ in terms of its relation to inflation, though real wages are still being squeezed there are signs that this should ease in the coming months â€“ while unemployment fell by 3000 to 1.44 million (the unemployment rate didnâ€™t actually change, remaining steady at 4.3%). NF Back with the UK data. From Simon French, chief economist at Panmure Gordon: Earlier, as well as the preliminary PMIs for France and Germany, there were also estimates for the eurozone as a whole. This showed the same pattern, with manufacturing slipping back in January and services rising. The eurozone manufacturing PMI dipped from 60.6 to 59.8 while services climbed from 56.6 to 57.6. The composite index rose from 58.1 to 58.6. Unicredit Bank economist Edoardo Campanella said: The eurozone starts 2018 with a bang, continuing to churn out solid economic figures. Januaryâ€™s Composite PMI hit a near 12-year high, rising to 58.6 from 58.1 and pointing to annualized GDP growth of almost 4%. Economic activity further accelerated in the services sector to the fastest pace since August 2007, while it slowed down in the manufacturing industry â€“ after having recorded an all-time high last December. NF The UK jobs data today shows the difficulties employers are having filling vacancies, especially those companies which use a large number of EU migrant workers, says theNational Institute of Economic and Social Research. Associate research director Dr Heather Rolfe said: UK labour market statistics released today show employment in the 3 months up to November 2017 is at a record high, driven by an increase in full time employment. However, vacancies are also at an all-time high, revealing difficulties for employers in some economic sectors, including those with a high proportion of migrant employees facing the challenges of Brexit. This reflects what employers who have engaged in our Brexit research say they are experiencing on the ground â€“ that they are losing some EU migrants and finding it more difficult to recruit both British and EU workers. The sectors with high vacancy rates include those with relatively high proportions of migrant employees, including from the EU. Accommodation and food services, where one in six workers are EU migrants is one such sector. The challenges of attracting and retaining workers are likely to increase with prolonged uncertainty about the terms of the UKâ€™s departure from the EU. NF Neil Wilson, senior market analyst at ETX Capital, said: Sterling breached $1.41 to record another post-Brexit high as a renewed bout of dollar softness and some better-than-expected employment numbers fuelled bids. Strong employment numbers were just the nudge the pound needed to get over $1.41, where it is just about holding at present. After showing signs of a slowdown, there was a strong bounce back in employment in December. Wage growth ex-bonuses rose by 2.4% compared to 2.3% in the quarter to October. Although below inflation at the present there are signs that tentatively rising wage growth will converge with falling inflation in the coming months. Sterlingâ€™s recovery will only aid that process and is a reason to be more bullish on the UK economy and sterling. Generally speaking we are also seeing less chance of the cliff-edge exit with the tone of Brexit negotiations more constructive since December following the UKâ€™s agreement to financial terms. But for all the chatter about Brexit and UK unemployment numbers, this is very much a soft dollar story. The dollar index has given up the 90 handle and we have the dollar below 110 against the yen for the first time since September and the euro has broken to a fresh three-year high. The pound is now well bid above its 50-, 100- and 200-day moving averages and with todayâ€™s blast above $1.41 seems set to consolidate above $1.40. There is not a huge amount of resistance on the upside for cable. The 50% retracement of the move from $1.71 to $1.19 is at $1.4590. Then we have the $1.4770 May 3rd 2016 high before the all-important $1.5000 level comes back into play. But these seem a long way off and depend entirely on dollar weakness to be sustained. For that we will look to Davos and what president Trump says with regards to trade. Concerns about trade wars â€“ put on the back burner last year as the administration battled with Obamacare and tax reform â€“ have resurfaced. Tariffs on washing machines and solar cells may only be the start, while there are ongoing worries about Nafta. Trade concerns are trumping the Trump tax policy as far as the dollar is concerned. And the focus on the dollarâ€™s slide seems to be dampening the mood generally in equity markets. Nevertheless, dollar softness may well be overdone and shorts could be squeezed when GDP figures for the fourth quarter are released, which are likely to confirm yet more acceleration in growth in the US and could see markets bet on a faster pace of tightening by the Fed than currently priced in. NF Real wages are still being squeezed in the UK according to the latest data, with pay growth including bonuses steady at 2.5% and despite an increase from 2.3% to 2.4% when bonuses are excluded. Ben Brettell, senior economist at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: With pay growing at 2.5% [including bonuses] and inflation running at 3.0%, the squeeze on real wages continues for the ninth consecutive month. But with inflation seemingly set to fall back towards the 2% target, this looks like itâ€™ll come to an end in the next few months. We should remember, however, that the only true driver of real pay growth and rising living standards is productivity growth. This is something the UK has struggled with since the financial crisis, and as yet nobody seems to have solved the puzzle. Suren Thiru, head of economics at the British Chambers of Commerce, said: While it is encouraging that regular earnings growth picked up slightly, subdued economic conditions are likely to weigh on wage growth over the next year. As a consequence, pay growth is likely to remain stubbornly below price growth over the near term, dampening consumer spending, a key driver of UK GDP growth. NF The president of Brazil, Michael Temer, is speaking now -- encouraging business leaders to provide fresh investment. Jasper Lawler, head of research at London Capital Group, said: The relentless rise in sterling, which has seen it jump over 3% in the last 10 days is looking durable. The good news for the economy is that more people are working with rising wages despite any uncertainty associated with leaving the European Union. Lord Jim Oâ€™Neil looks vindicated so far in his belief that strong domestic and global growth will overcome Brexit headwinds. Matthew Brittain, investment analyst at wealth manager Sanlam UK, said: The real worry [for the UK economy] is centred around the consumer where wages have been increasing at a lower rate than inflation (ie falling in â€œrealâ€� terms). So another bright spot in this release is that weekly earnings ticked up from 2.3 to 2.4% versus a year ago, which is still lower than inflation (3%) but at least the gap is steadily being closed Since the data makes it slightly more likely that the Bank of England will increase interest rates later on in the year the immediate reaction is a rise in sterling to Â£1.41 with bonds and equities both under a little pressure. NF Sterling has climbed above $1.41 against the dollar after the better than expected UK unemployment and wages data. It is up 0.7%, a new peak since the Brexit vote but still below the $1.4878 level on the day of the referendum itself. Against the euro sterling is up 0.3% at â‚¬1.1416. The pound is benefitting from the signs of a stronger economy, and growing hopes that a Brexit deal can be reached. It is also being helped by the weakness of the dollar, which has fallen even more after the comments from US Treasury secretary Stephen Mnuchin at Davos. The US currency has been under pressure since the tax cuts announcement, with fears the reforms would push the countryâ€™s huge deficit even higher. News of trade sanctions against South Korea and China have not helped, prompting fears of retaliation. Dennis de Jong, managing director of UFX.com, said: Sterling has bounced back in fine style, particularly against the dollar where it has climbed above $1.40 for the first time since the historic Brexit vote. Unemployment continues to fall, while there are signs that wages are finally growing, with employees willing to take more risks to ask for a pay rise, or even consider moving jobs. Although nothing has been decided yet, the general consensus is that the final version of Brexit could be softer than previously thought, which can only be good for the UK economy as a whole. NF Hereâ€™s more details from former UK PM Tony Blair at Davos (speaking on Bloomberg TV) Asked whether there was any other way to avoid Brexit apart from having a second referendum, Blair said: â€œYou could have a general election. â€œIf we do go through with Brexit - and I hope we donâ€™t - itâ€™s going to be a complete change and we will have to fashion a new future for the country.â€� He said that when people have clarity on what the Brexit deal might look like - and he suspects it will be â€œhotch potchâ€� - â€œI think it will be very difficult to persuade people thatâ€™s better than what we have now.â€� Q: What is he expecting from Trumpâ€™s speech on Friday? â€œI donâ€™t know what to expect. For me the issue is not responding to what Donald Trump has just said, itâ€™s the reasons that brought him to power ... the cultural and economic alienation ... this is the root of the problem that needs to be addressed.â€� UK employment rose unexpectedly in the three months to November, while wages rose by a higher than forecast 2.4%, excluding bonuses. The number of people in work rose by 102,000 in the quarter, said the Office for National Statistics, the biggest increase since the three months to July. Analysts had expected a fall of 13,000. The unemployment rate was steady at a four decade low of 4.3%. As for wages, the 2.4% figure was up from 2.3% in the three months to October and better than the forecasts of a flat reading. With inflation slipping back from 3.1% to 3% in November, the wage gap has edged lower. Total pay growth including bonuses was steady at 2.5%, as forecast. NF While the German and French leaders are at Davos, there is some reasonable data from both countries. The latest manufacturing PMIs for the two have come in below expectations but the service sector has outperformed. For France the preliminary manufacturing PMI for January came in at 58.1, down from 58.8. The services PMI rose from 59.1 to 59.3, with the composite PMI up from 59.6 to 59.7. In Germany the manufacturing index fell from 63.3 to 61.2, the services rose from 55.8 to 57 but the composite slipped from 58.9 to 58.8 NF The US dollar is sliding like an ill-prepared delegate on the streets of Davos, thanks to Stephen Mnuchin. The Treasury secretaryâ€™s comment about not being worried about the weak dollar has sparked another wave of selling, sending the greenback to a fresh three-year low. Former chancellor George Osborne says the vote for Brexit was â€œan alliance of the insulated and the insecureâ€�. In a discussion on the causes of Brexit and Donald Trumpâ€™s victory Osborne said the insulated were elderly voters who owned their homes outright but were anxious about the pace of change while the insecure were â€œon the margins of employment and looking for something to address their grievances.â€� That was a classic good-cop/bad cop performance from Stephen Mnuchin and Wilbur Ross at Davos this morning. Mnuchin tried to calm concerns ahead of Donald Trumpâ€™s visit, by insisting that America First wasnâ€™t incompatible with working with other countries. But Ross was more combative, insisting that America had been treated badly by other nations in the past, and that Trump is simply levelling the score. Ross comments about â€œUS troops coming to the rampartsâ€�, and other countries talking about free trade but actually being protectionist, are a hint about how the US will behave behind the scenes at the World Economic Forum this week. Hereâ€™s some reaction: Final question -- will the US be reassuring delegates at Davos that it isnâ€™t creating a â€˜race to the bottomâ€™ on tax? Stephen Mnuchin replies that heâ€™s always been clear with fellow finance ministers that this isnâ€™t Americaâ€™s objective. This was about creating a comparable system for US companies to compete fairly, and we see that working. Q: What retaliations do you think China might take if the US imposes new tariffs? Every time you take a trade action, there is the possibility of the other side taking a trade action in retaliation, Wilbur Ross replies. To the degree that this happens, thereâ€™s also a question about what the US would do next, Ross continues. Boom! Asked about the dangers of a trade war, US commerce secretary Wilbur Ross argues that it has been underway for some time. The difference is that the US troops are now coming to the ramparts. Stephen Mnuchin denies that thereâ€™s a clash between America being â€˜open for businessâ€™ and President Trumpâ€™s economic goals. This is about an America First agenda, but America First does mean working with the rest of the world. President Trump is looking out for US workers and US interest, just as heâ€™d expect other world leaders to do, Mnuchin adds. Q: How concerned are you about the weakness of the US dollar? The dollar is one of the most liquid markets. Where it is in the short term is not a concern at all, says Mnuchin. A weaker US dollar is good for trade, he continues. And in the long term, the strength of the US dollar is a sign of the strength of the US economy. Q: Have you any evidence that your tax reforms are boosting investment? The vote from the market is â€˜pretty positiveâ€™, Mnuchin replies. Weâ€™ve seen many companies come out and commit hundreds of millions of dollars, if not billions of dollars, he says - citing Apple as an example. We couldnâ€™t be happier. The response from US businesses has been even better than we expected. Q: How does the America First economic agenda match up to the World Economic Forumâ€™s goals? Our objective is to be here to interact with our counterparts. Thatâ€™s very important for the worldâ€™s biggest economy, Mnuchin replies. Commerce secretary Wilbur Ross weighs in too, repeating that some of Americaâ€™s trading partners are protectionist, even if they talk about free trade. We donâ€™t think that adhering to the rules is protectionist. We think in fact it is essential to having markets operate properly, to have people play by the rules. Q: Are you worried that China might cut its holdings of US government debt? Treasury secretary Mnuchin says that some of the reporting of this issue has been inaccurate. The market for US treasuries is â€˜deepâ€™, he adds. Q: Is there a bubble in the United States financial markets? Mnuchin says that forums like Davos are never very good at predicting markets. What we see in the US markets is a reaction to the economic changes weâ€™ve made, he suggests - but he doesnâ€™t want to comment on other markets. As we look at US economic growth against the rest of the world, US economic growth looks very good - and itâ€™s a good place to invest, he continues. Q: What do you think about Justin Trudeauâ€™s comments about NAFTA yesterday? We totally believe in full and free trade - anyone who wants to do it on a reciprocal basis are very welcome, Stephen Mnuchin replies. Q: What might you do next against China over protectionism? Wilbur Ross: There are a number of other actions pending. Reports have been drawn up for President Trump to consider (he references the aluminium market) There will be a very busy trade agenda in terms of those actions by the US, and there are the formal actions with relation to NAFTA, Ross adds. Commerce secretary Wilbur Ross speaks next, and rubbishes the idea that the US tax cuts are creating a new trade barrier This is a â€œfunny conceptâ€�, Ross says: The US has been on an uncompetitive model before, but it is now on a very competitive one. Ross also touches on free trade -- and insists that any actions taken by America are in response to â€œinappropriate behaviourâ€� by Americaâ€™s trading partners. Many countries are very good at the rhetoric of free trade, but actually practice protectionism. Stephen Mnuchin, the US Treasury secretary, has just arrived at a packed-out press briefing here at Davos. Heâ€™s accompanied by Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross. Mnuchin begins by saying heâ€™s thrilled to be at Davos, with the largest US delegation to WEF ever. Obviously tax reforms and tax cuts were a major part of what we achieved in Donald Trumpâ€™s first year, Mnuchin says - which will bring â€œliterally trillions of dollarsâ€� back to the UK. We are committed to achieving a 3% growth target, Mnuchin continued. And thatâ€™s not just good for the US, itâ€™s good for the world economy too. Mnuchin declares: We are open for business, and we look forward to being here through the week. Former UK prime minister Tony Blair is in town! He just spoke to Bloomberg TV about the need for â€œprogressive centerismâ€�. More on that later... The boss of Lloyds of London has warned that the focus on dry economic measures such as GDP has helped to create the backlash that led to Brexit. Speaking to CNBC at the World Economic Forum, Inga Beale said policymakers need to think differently about how they measure the economy. Beale explained: I do remember, when we were going through the campaigning around Brexit, in the UK, we, as businesses, were talking about GDP. Most of the members of the public donâ€™t even know what that means, you know, they-, it doesnâ€™t relate to them. And thereâ€™s a definite feeling that theyâ€™re not being included, and they want to challenge the, you know, the â€˜as isâ€™, at the moment. They really want to go out and say, â€˜Iâ€™m not happy with this status quo. Youâ€™re not hearing me. Youâ€™re not respecting me. Iâ€™m not included.â€™ And when we talk about GDP, that doesnâ€™t feel very inclusive for them. On Monday, the World Economic Forum did launch a new, more inclusive measure of economic performance that also tracked inequality and sustainability. Britain came just 21st. Sounds like Emmanuel Macron is only paying a flying visit.. Last night, around 2000 demonstrators in Zurich marched in protest at Donald Trumpâ€™s visit to the World Economic Forum. Reuters reports that a small group even managed to demonstrate here in Davos: About 20 demonstrators broke through security to reach the Davos Congress Centre, holding banners and shouting â€œWipe out WEFâ€� before they were peacefully disbanded by police. â€œTrump is just one of the other people we disagree with. Weâ€™ve been protesting every year now against the World Economic Forum and if Trump comes or not we donâ€™t care. Trump is just, maybe heâ€™s just the best symbol of this world,â€� protester Alex Hedinger told Reuters TV in Davos. More here. Now this is interesting.... Treasury secretary Stephen Mnuchin is going to give a briefing at Davos in around 30 minutes. Todayâ€™s meeting is billed â€œWe are open for businessâ€� - perhaps an attempt to calm worries over President Trumpâ€™s America First agenda.... Good morning. The second day of the World Economic is getting underway, with a strong European flavour. German chancellor Angela Merkel, French president Emmanuel Macron and Italian prime minister Paolo Gentiloni are all due on the Davos main stage today - a chance to set the agenda before Donald Trumpâ€™s eagerly-awaited speech on Friday. But the Americans are already fighting for the spotlight. US Treasury secretary Stephen Mnuchin is in town, and speaking to the press this morning (weâ€™ll hopefully have more on that soon). Spainâ€™s King Filipe, and the presidents of Brazil and Zimbabwe are also making appearances. Plus, Davos delegates will be discussing economic inequality (despite the obvious irony), slavery, and the opportunity and threats posed by technology. Thereâ€™s even a footballer in town. Manchester Unitedâ€™s Juan Mata will be pushing his Common Goal charitable fund, which encourages sports stars to donate some of their massive salaries to good causes. Hereâ€™s some of the events weâ€™ll try to cover: 10am Davos (9am GMT): IMF chief Christine Lagarde on â€œSolving the Economic Generation Gapâ€� 10.20am Davos (9.20am GMT): Special Address by Michel Temer, President of Brazil 11.15am Davos (10.15am GMT): Spainâ€™s King Felipe VI speaks 12.30pm Davos (11.30am GMT): Session on â€˜Stabilizing the Mediterraneanâ€™ with Italian PM Paolo Gentiloni and Greeceâ€™s Alexis Tsipras 2pm Davos (1pm GMT): Zimbabwe President Emmerson Mnangagwa speaks 2.20pm Davos (1.20pm GMT): Special Address by Angela Merkel, Chancellor of Germany 3.30pm Davos (2.30pm GMT): Google Chief Executive Sundar Pichai on AI and technologyâ€™s impact on society 4pm Davos (3pm GMT): A session on how to end slavery 5.30pm Davos (4.30pm GMT): Special Address by Emmanuel Macron, President of France 6pm Davos (5pm GMT): Manchester Unitedâ€™s Juan Mata talks about his Common Goal charitable work

9.23pm GMT

A late PS, from the Associated Pressâ€™s Pan Pylas on the moment Trump arrived at the World Economic Forum.

One way to get President Donald Trump to stop and talk at the World Economic Forum: wield a book about him.

On his way into the World Economic Forum, Trump stopped and talked for about ten seconds to one delegate who was brandishing a copy of â€œGod and Donald Trumpâ€� by Stephen E. Strang. He then proceeded to hold the book aloft in his left hand.

Trump is the first U.S. president to attend the World Economic Forum since Bill Clinton back in 2000.

Trump is holding a series of meetings and is due to deliver a speech on Friday in which he will argue that what is good for the U.S. economy is beneficial for the global economy.

9.20pm GMT

In the real world, outside the Davos bubble of Alpine restaurants and chalets, the global economic system they have built isnâ€™t working for billions of people. â€œAnd just as Davos faces the risk of an avalanche this week, growth for a few risks a political and social avalanche unless there is fundamental change to our rigged economic system. Philip Hammond, the UKâ€™s chancellor of the Exchequer, is also at Davos. Heâ€™s been giving his views about artificial intelligence at a Microsoft breakfast, saying: â€œWe are at the point where computers move from being dumb and fast to being smart and fast.â€� Hammond says AI is going to be disruptive and managing the process is the key to it being accepted, warning: â€œTo many it will seem to be a big threat to their prosperity and livelihoodsâ€�. The UK PM is expected to put technology giants under pressure to clean up their act and tackle extreme content. Sheâ€™ll say: Investors can make a big difference here by ensuring trust and safety issues are being properly considered. And I urge them to do so. Facebook and Google have become â€œobstacles to innovationâ€� and are a â€œmenaceâ€� to society whose â€œdays are numberedâ€�, said billionaire investor and philanthropist George Soros at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Thursday.

â€œMining and oil companies exploit the physical environment; social media companies exploit the social environment,â€� said the Hungarian-American businessman, according to a transcript of his speech.

â€œThis is particularly nefarious because social media companies influence how people think and behave without them even being aware of it. This has far-reaching adverse consequences on the functioning of democracy, particularly on the integrity of elections.â€�

In addition to skewing democracy, social media companies â€œdeceive their users by manipulating their attention and directing it towards their own commercial purposesâ€� and â€œdeliberately engineer addiction to the services they provideâ€�. The latter, he said, â€œcan be very harmful, particularly for adolescentsâ€�.

Related: Tech's terrible year: how the world turned on Silicon Valley in 2017

â€œThe power to shape peopleâ€™s attention is increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few companies. It takes a real effort to assert and defend what John Stuart Mill called â€˜the freedom of mindâ€™. There is a possibility that once lost, people who grow up in the digital age will have difficulty in regaining it. This may have far-reaching political consequences.â€�

Soros warned of an â€œeven more alarming prospectâ€� on the horizon if data-rich internet companies such as Facebook and Google paired their corporate surveillance systems with state-sponsored surveillance â€“ a trend thatâ€™s already emerging in places such as the Philippines.

â€œThis may well result in a web of totalitarian control the likes of which not even Aldous Huxley or George Orwell could have imagined,â€� he said.

The companies, which he described as â€œever more powerful monopoliesâ€� are unlikely to change their behaviour without regulation.

â€œThe internet monopolies have neither the will nor the inclination to protect society against the consequences of their actions. That turns them into a menace and it falls to the regulatory authorities to protect society against them,â€� he said.

He said Davos was a good place to announce: â€œTheir days are numbered.â€�

He also echoed the words of world wide web inventor Sir Tim Berners-Lee when he said the tech giants had become â€œobstacles to innovationâ€� that need to be regulated as public utilities â€œaimed at preserving competition, innovation and fair and open universal accessâ€�.

During the same speech, Soros also criticised Donald Trumpâ€™s leadership, saying he had put the US on course for a nuclear war with North Korea.

Soros is the latest high-profile business person to speak out about these internet platforms at Davos. Earlier this week, Salesforceâ€™s chief executive, Marc Benioff, said that Facebook should be regulated like a cigarette company because itâ€™s addictive and harmful.

In November, Roger McNamee, who was an early investor in Facebook, described Facebook and Google as threats to public health.

In the same month Facebookâ€™s founding chairman, Sean Parker, criticised his former employer: â€œGod only knows what itâ€™s doing to our childrenâ€™s brains,â€� he said.

fields.body:
Businesses are learning to live with Trump

A year ago, the global elite was still in shock after the US presidential election. Many business leaders had planned to leave WEF early to fly to Washington for Hillary Clintonâ€™s inauguration, rather than to watch Trump take oath of office.

What a difference a year, and a massive tax cut, makes.

Trump confirmed that the way to a chief executiveâ€™s heart and mind is through their wallet, when he got 15 European business leaders to join him for dinner. Fawning was on the menu alongside grilled beef tenderloin, as several bosses expressed their gratitude for the presidentâ€™s tax cut and policy of deregulation.

The corporate world seems happy to suppress any concerns over Trumpâ€™s wider behaviour. It may not like what he says, but it likes what heâ€™s doing.

Social media in the dock

The days of kowtowing to Facebook, Google and Twitter are over. Social media was kicked from one end of the Davos promenade to the other this year, chastised for failing to control extremist content and for hooking young people onto an unhealthy diet of updates, selfies and likes.

George Soros launched the most stinging attack, saying social media giants were exploiting the social environment and undermining democracy. Hours earlier, Theresa May had lashed out at them for giving a helping hand to terrorists and child abusers.

Time really is up for sexual harassment

News of the sordid behaviour at Britainâ€™s Presidents Club charity dinner filtered up to the Davos ski resort slowly (perhaps delegates had another president on their mind). But as the Financial Timesâ€™s report did the rounds, business leaders visibly blanched at the details of groping and sexual harassment and quickly checked the guest list to find out whether any of their employees had been in attendance.

The previous evening, Canadaâ€™s Justin Trudeau had called for a â€œcritical discussionâ€� on womenâ€™s rights and equality. His speech resonated through the hall, but what really shook business chiefs was the possibility their firm had been on the Presidents Club invite list.

Malala Yousafzai told WEF that women must â€œraise up their voicesâ€� to end harassment, and business chiefs seemed to be listening.

Education must be reimagined to handle AI

World leaders fear that millions of old economy jobs will be crushed by the fourth Industrial Revolution, while business leaders fret that workers wonâ€™t have the skills needed for the new technology age.

So whatâ€™s the solution? The word on the WEF floor is that education needs a major shake-up. The Lego Foundation chief, John Goodwin, warns that too many countries are still using education practices â€œestablished at the time of our grandparentsâ€�. That could be disastrous, with data showing two-thirds of primary children will go into jobs that donâ€™t even exist yet.

Davos has outgrown Davos

The theme of this yearâ€™s annual meeting was â€œCreating a Shared Future in a Fractured Worldâ€�. But WEF itself felt pretty fractured this year.

Thatâ€™s partly thanks to the extra kerfuffle created by Trump, who overshadowed events at Davos even before he landed. But even before then, the flaws in holding a gathering of world leaders and business chiefs in a tiny ski resort were painfully obvious.

Even when it runs smoothly, Davos is a wild cocktail of keynote speeches, top-level meetings and intimate sessions. â€œIâ€™m constantly feeling Fomo â€“ fear of missing out,â€� joked one senior UK delegate. Add to that the worst snow in decades, which brought the already glacial traffic to a complete halt, and you start to think that Davos has outgrown Davos.

fields.body:
One of the biggest surprises about Rupert Murdochâ€™s decision to sell his entertainment assets to Disney was his willingness to part company with Sky, the UKâ€™s biggest pay-TV broadcaster. But some analysts are now asking whether Disney, which has agreed to buy a 39% stake in Sky as part of a $66bn deal to buy most of the tycoonâ€™s 21st Century Fox group, needs the pay-TV arm either.

This concern lingers in the background as the UK competition regulator mulls Foxâ€™s attempt to take full control of Sky â€“ a deal that is still going ahead in parallel with the Disney transaction. Murdochâ€™s Â£11.7bn bid to buy Sky is still in doubt after the Competition and Markets Authority said the deal could be blocked because it would give his family too much influence over the UK news media.

Meanwhile, analysts ponder whether this subplot in one of the decadeâ€™s least-expected media deals will be much of a distraction for Disney, the giant theme park, film studio and TV network group.

â€œDisney wants Sky, but doesnâ€™t need it,â€� said Brian Wieser of equity analysis group Pivotal Research. â€œThere is a strategic value to Sky, but it would potentially be willing to sell at a certain price. There is a price for everything.â€�

Disney has already signalled to the UKâ€™s Panel on Takeovers and Mergers, the City watchdog for corporate deals, that if Foxâ€™s deal to buy the 61% of Sky it doesnâ€™t already own fails, it does not wish to be forced to pursue a full takeover. For Disney, a bigger distraction than Sky is the strategic quandary posed by new competitors from the tech industry. Given the rapid digitisation of the global media industry, Disney is increasingly focusing on the rising threats of Netflix, Amazon, Apple and Google.

Disneyâ€™s chief executive, Bob Iger, described Sky as a â€œcrown jewelâ€� asset when the Fox transaction was announced in December. But he must consider whether Skyâ€™s platform is the best answer in the UK to the threat posed by the tech giants.

Last week Netflixâ€™s stock market valuation surged past $100bn (Disneyâ€™s is almost $170bn) for the first time after it revealed a record quarter of new subscribers, driving its global user base to 117 million.

As the largest entertainment company in the world, Disney boldly decided to flex its muscles and cut out the digital middleman. It has removed its content from Netflix in the US and announced plans for two streaming services. One of these â€“ for its ESPN sports network, which has rights to prime American leagues such as the NFL and NBA â€“ will be launched later this year. In 2019, it will launch a second service for its vast film and TV catalogue, which spans the Marvel universe (the Avengers, Iron Man and Captain America series), the Star Wars franchise, Pixar films such as Toy Story and Finding Nemo, and traditional Disney productions such as Frozen and The Lion King. Disney is launching the venture in the US initially, but Iger, who has made it clear that Disney is looking to a future where viewers get content via the internet rather than cable and satellite TV, has indicated that it will become a global service.

Sky is continuing to develop its own streaming service, Now TV, to take on Netflix and Amazon. But Disney has spent $1.5bn on technology to build its own facilities and may not need both.

â€œSky is mostly the old-guard, traditional TV,â€� said Sarah Simon of research firm Berenberg. â€œDisney may think it can create more value with its own direct-to-consumer platform than by holding a 39% stake in Sky. If you are in a streaming model, why do you need to own Sky? Now TV could become its streaming platform in the UK, but itâ€™s quite a big price to pay for a bit of [streaming] technology you already have.â€�

Disney, like other major Hollywood studios including Fox, also has an exclusive deal, which expires in 2020, for its films to run on Sky first. Buying Murdochâ€™s 20th Century Fox, the fourth largest Hollywood studio, will add content including the X-Men films, Avatar, Titanic and Deadpool as well as TV shows such as The Simpsons.

According to sources, Disney has been gearing up to pull its content from Netflix in the UK â€“ its second-biggest market globally â€“ in order to make its services a must-have. This strategy could also ultimately spell the end of Skyâ€™s exclusive movie deals with Disney and Fox, too.

â€œWith the additional content from the Fox deal, I think Disney will look to pull its content from Netflix in the UK,â€� said Simon. â€œIts new digital strategy is to go directly to consumers, but if you donâ€™t make content exclusive, what is the point? I think Disney content would have been pulled from Sky in due course regardless.â€�

Disney may also have a wary eye on Skyâ€™s first-run TV deal with Game of Thrones maker HBO, which expires in 2020, and could come under renewal pressure as HBO is also beginning to build its own streaming services in the US and Europe. Indeed, cable service HBO could go it alone with a Disney-type streaming channel and remove all of its content from Sky eventually.

The issue of sports rights, which account for the lionâ€™s share of Skyâ€™s Â£7bn annual content budget, could be another significant concern for Disney. Sky will have to pay in excess of Â£5bn to secure the prime matches in the upcoming Premier League rights auction for 2019-22, an estimated 15%-23% more than last time, with the bids for those seasons due in two weeks.

Inflation has been rampant: the total rights sold for just a third of that (Â£1.78bn) as recently as the three-season deal from 2010-11.

The spectre of a deep-pocketed digital rival for Premier League rights such as Amazon spurring further price inflation or, worse, ultimately taking the best packages of matches, could weigh on how Disney sees the long game of owning Sky.

â€œFootball is such a big part of this,â€� said Berenbergâ€™s Simon. â€œSky makes money, but that depends on the price of [football] rights and the direction of profits. What will happen in the next football rights auction in two more years? They could cost more, or less, or Amazon could be in the football market. Sky says it has reduced its reliance on football, but that is an illusion. Everyone is making high-end drama, and the picture would be very different if HBO were to go, Amazon took some football packages, and some movie deals went. [Disney chief executive] Bob Iger has said Sky is a crown jewel but it will depend massively on how the landscape looks in two years.â€�

Pivotalâ€™s Wieser said that if Murdochâ€™s Sky bid was blocked by the CMA but Disney launched its own takeover bid, the US media group could face serious competition. He points out Comcast â€“ which owns assets including NBC, CNBC, Syfy, Universal Pictures and DreamWorks Animation â€“ as a potential suitor.

â€œDisney will try to buy it, but it wonâ€™t be the only one,â€� he says. â€œSky will have no shortage of interest â€“Comcast for example. Who knows where the market will be in 18 months when they would think about making a bid [for the rest of Sky]?â€�

Nonetheless, an educated guess would probably point to Netflix being an even bigger threat by then. If the Fox deal goes ahead, Disney faces a dilemma with Sky.
